pages.text: Palaeodiphasia simplex comes from the Upper Cambrian, with fossils found in the Fengshan Formation, North China. It is a branched hydrozoan and grew up to 1 cm in height. Palaeodiphasia was originally assigned under the genus 'Siberiograptus' as 'S. simplex', which is apart of the subclass graptolite, until recent further study showed this not to be the case.
The generic name derives from the Greek word 'Palaeo', to mean 'old'; and the genus name 'Diphasia'. The specific name derives from the Latin word 'simplex', to mean 'simple'.
